claim: Let A = {(x, y) ∈ ℝ² : y = x² - 4}, B = {(p, q) ∈ ℤ² : q < 0}, and C = {(a, b) ∈ ℝ² : |a| ≤ 1}. Prove that A ∩ B ⊆ C.
solution: Let (x, y) ∈ A ∩ B. This means (x, y) ∈ A and (x, y) ∈ B. From A, we know y = x² - 4. From B, we know x, y are integers and y < 0. Since y = x² - 4 and y < 0, we have x² - 4 < 0, which implies x² < 4. Since x is an integer (from B), the possible values for x are -1, 0, 1. For all these values, |x| ≤ 1. Thus, (x, y) satisfies the condition for set C. Therefore, (x, y) ∈ C, proving A ∩ B ⊆ C.
